title: Has the rock music genre declined because it has become too difficult to create an original sound? - Quora

response.answer_text: Rock 'n' roll is around 70 years old, and inevitably by this time so many melodies, riffs and lyrical themes have already been explored. However, this does not mean that the genre is doomed to decline from here on out. There are an inexhaustible number of ways that artists can give their own twists to themes that have been visited before, perhaps mixing and matching. The roots of pizza, for example, go back hundreds, maybe thousands of years. Yet a pizza eaten today is just as delicious. Robert Plant has said that everyone borrows from everyone else. It's hard to disagree with him. Sometimes this borrowing is blatant (Creed from Pearl Jam; Greta Van Fleet from Led Zeppelin, etc.) and sometimes it's more subtle. The roots of rock music today can be traced back to several prominent ancestors: Chuck Berry, Elvis Presley, The Beatles, The Rolling Stones, Bob Dylan, The Who, Buddy Holly, The Beach Boys, The Byrds, Hank Williams (a country artist, but he had an outsized impact on rock), Bo Diddley, Little Richard, James Brown, Led Zeppelin and others. Their musical DNA, along with that of many more, has mingled to produce today's rock music. Going outside of rock music to the field of country for a second, the vast majority of the new acts of the last thirty years have been just as influenced by the Eagles and Lynyrd Skynyrd as by George Jones and Merle Haggard. So, later generations can change the course of a genre and influence it going forward. A hundred years from now, long after we're gone, someone will probably hear a Chuck Berry song and want to pick up a guitar. She or he will give the music their own spin and perhaps go on to inspire others.

I think this is an important part of the reason, though not the only reason. Some previous movements in rock, such as 1970s punk and 2000s pop punk, were quite back-to-basics in their nature. And with the stagnation of music-making technology at the turn of the millennium, there’s plenty of retro-sounding music in the other genres. Look at how much disco-influenced pop we have had this year. As for other reasons, in the 1970s, dissatisfied working-class youth did not have access to sampling and drum machines. So the easiest way for them to create a musical outlet for their dissatisfaction was to form a rock band. Although it did not happen overnight, rapping has now become the easiest way to form an outlet. Computer production has become as easy and accessible as buying and learning to play a guitar, and has the added advantage in that you can do it on your own. There’s also the fact that any genre is likely to have a shelf life in terms of being popular. If rock is following the trajectory of jazz, then rock is in the same position jazz was in the mid-80s, about 65 years after it first became popular. By that time, jazz was quite clearly no longer part of the cultural zeitgeist. Furthermore, it had also stagnated artistically, a contrast to the first half of the 1970s. As one answer to another recent question put it, while we usually expect teenagers to rebel against the music of their parents, it’s actually when a genre becomes the music of their grandparents that it really loses its footing.

Let’s start off with the premise that “the rock music genre has declined”, as there are still vital regional markets and venues for so-called rock music, and so the “decline” is more in the market percentage rather than a complete wipe-out. One might even posit that the music has “gone underground”. One could also posit that the fundamental shift in “popular music” has to do with technology, as currently it’s the “one man/woman band”; the producer’s studio being housed in someone’s bedroom; the “band” being a mass of samples or computer generated loops. So . . . saying one genre is in decline or even “dead”, reverts to what people have been bemoaning about the state of jazz for quite a while. It’s more like DNA or the genes have been passed along, so you can say so-and-so looks like jazz but of course it’s not jazz’s grandpa (the exact same person). The grandpa might have gone to the great hereafter but the son/daughter live on in the specifics of their era. Listen closely! Clearly, rock has had an influence, simply in terms of “sonic energy” on that market juggernaut we call hip-hop, a genre which surely does NOT sound like it sounded in 1980-whatever.

response.answer_text: I don't think so, I still hear plenty of original sounding rock music, but it is probably harder to find these days. Rock does, however have to compete in a changing media landscape which currently seems to favour other genres, some of which prioritise “fame” over originality. The other problem that's been around for years is that record companies are less inclined to nurture rising talent. They want a hit. NOW! And they want money for their shareholders. NOW! We no longer seem to have labels like Charisma, Island or the early Virgin records whose owners were just glad to take a punt on something interesting. I doubt that Tubular Bells would get a release these days.

response.answer_text: Since you asked, I’ll weigh in a little against the others who answered so far: No, originality has never been a crucial part of rock and roll; in fact there has always been more ancestor worship in rock than most popular genres. There certainly has been some originality, and those who brought it were sometimes rewarded — but not always. For every Peter Gabriel there have been a raft of Bruce Springsteens and Bryan Adamses and John Cougar Mellencamps. The big changes, that is, the big spikes of originality, have usually come from other genres — R&B, funk, even New Wave (though most of that wore off). The changes rock could claim for its own, like punk and grunge, are mainly reversions to rock’s own roots.

It has become too difficult to both create an original sound and get a hit. Otherwise, it hasn’t - just make the music that you think sounds good, and don’t worry about what’s getting played on the radio. If you like something you heard on the radio, go ahead and sound like that. If you like something from your uncle’s record collection that was never a hit, go ahead and sound like that. And, if you hear something in your head you’ve never heard before, or your fingers on your instrument lead you there, go ahead and sound like that.

Original sound has nothing to do with it. No matter what the genre, sounding like other artists within that genre is par for the course. There are a list of boxes that a song or artist has to tick to be rock, the decline has more to do with new genres fitting new sound better than rock could. Most modern music has roots in folk and classical, but we don’t call them by either of those words because there’s been whole new categories created to better suit what they’re creating. Making original sound is the easy part, calling it rock music is where it gets difficult.

response.answer_text: Maybe. Rock music has been around for over 70 years (depending on when you date the first rock record). There have been myriad styles. But it’s still basically 3-chord blues progressions, sometimes with country, jazz or gospel elements. In over 70 years, most things have been done. This isn’t to say that some innovator won’t come along and break some new ground, but it’s definitely more difficult to be original with the back catalogue of the genre behind you.
